alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for assets made available to an employee
overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers who make assets available to employees
title: Expenses and benefits: assets made available to an employee

table.body:
As an employer making assets available for use by your employees, you have certain tax, National Insurance and reporting obligations.

##What's included

Assets can include:

- computers
- televisions
- bicycles

% [Cars](/expenses-and-benefits-company-cars "Company cars"), [vans](/expenses-and-benefits-company-vans "vans") and [living accommodation](/expenses-and-benefits-accommodation "living accommodation") aren't covered in this guide - these are reported separately. %

If you transfer ownership to your employee, see the guide on [assets bought, sold or given](/expenses-and-benefits-assets-bought-sold-or-given "assets bought, sold or given").
table.title: Overview

table.body:
You don’t have to report anything to HMRC or pay National Insurance on the asset if:

- the employee who uses it earns [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of less than £8,500 a year
- it's office equipment provided just for business use

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What's exempt

table.body:
If the asset isn’t [exempt](assets-made-available-to-an-employee-reporting-expenses-and-benefits/whats-exempt "exempt"), you must report it to HMRC and may have to pay National Insurance on it.

##Assets for business use only

^You can apply for a [dispensation](/apply-for-a-dispensation "dispensation"), which means you won’t have to include assets for business use on your end-of-year reports.^

If your employee earns [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of more than £8,500 a year, or they're a director, you'll have to:

- report on form P11D, section L
- pay nothing

##Assets for personal and business use

If your employee earns [at a rate](/employer-reporting-introduction-to-expenses-and-benefits/calculate-earnings-at-a-rate "at a rate") of more than £8,500 a year, or they're a director, you'll have to:

- report on form P11D, section L
- pay Class 1A National Insurance on the value of the benefit

*[HMRC]:HM Revenue & Customs
table.title: What to report and pay

table.body:
There are 2 steps to working out how much your asset is worth:

s1. Take the greater of either the asset's annual value or the rental or hire charges you pay for it.
s2. Add anything else you've spent on the asset during the year, eg running costs.

^ The asset’s annual value is 20% of its market value when you first provided it as an employee benefit. ^

You should reduce the value proportionately if either of the following applies:

- you made the asset available to more than one employee during the year
- you used the asset directly for your business during the year in some other way than making it available to your employee
